question: Labor Day weekend. Some time for a sanitation strike. Everybody crazy to stock up. They decide to score at the last minute and want it now. Never fails. The faces look alike. You gotta use memory tricks
Ann.
answer: Have we made New York safe for another weekend?

question: Did what's-his-name give you a hard time?

Yeah -- big kiss. "Labor Day." "Union Movement" -- there's a contradiction in terms. I know about long hours. It's worse when I'm off -- I just walk and walk. Where am I going? There's an element of providence to it all. Like rolling numbers. Luck. You're walking down the street, some guy that looks maybe a little like you does a stick-up four hours ago, there's an APB description out and a cop pulls you in cause he's cold and wants to go inside -- they grab your stash. Your number's up. You're busted for nothing. For bad luck.
answer: Five p.m. A Clinton transient hotel. Are they "faced"?

question: Don't bore me.
answer: Is it so much work to face them the same direction? You don't do it, I got to. It's time -- my time --

question: Jees --
answer: We've been through all this. This nineteen-gram shit is a drag.

question: We pay you more, you put up with more. White drugs for white people. Twice the price, twice the safety.
answer: I can't believe Ann's been working as long as she has -- never busted. She's something.

question: Never made any big money either.
She blows it.
answer: You believe that? What you gonna do after she quits? How long you been with her?

question: She always says that. We'll see, Jealous.
answer: She's out. You should pick up her trade. You're too old to be a go- fer. They know you, they trust you.

question: No way. I'm not the management type. I get in charge, I'll start using again -- not for me. I know music people. I'm gonna get in recording.
What?
answer: Normally this wouldn't matter to you, but you may get hassled.

question: Why?
answer: You read the papers? The Park murder. All over the Post. Mariah Rangel -- nineteen-year-old Barnard co-ed bitch dead in Turtle Pond coked to the fucking gills. All of a sudden they're hot after mid-level dealers. They're buzzin'. You know her?

question: I look like an encyclopedia? Who knows? Thanks for the warning.
answer: Jack. You pick up from Jealous?

question: Yeah, nineteen grams after four times last night. We're certainly not his favorite people.
answer: We don't make the laws. Nineteen is carrying, twenty is dealing. Let him be stupid.

question: He took my hundreds.
answer: Take over for a while. I'm getting contact high.

question: Who's Her Majesty talking to?
answer: The Ecstasy connection. From Arizona. She's trying to get them to come here -- or, better, Europe.

question: Don't dress. You really think she means it?
answer: That's what she says. New Year's Eve and out -- no Acid House, no product, no deliveries.

question: "Akasha"?
answer: Cosmetics. That's what Ann's calling the company now --

question: -- this week. I don't get it -- marigolds, violets, sage -- why'd anyone pay to put weeds on their face?
answer: Why'd anyone pay to put them up their nose? I like cosmetics. I need cosmetics. You should come in with us.

question: You forget
answer: Johnny! Robert! Come here! Plant me two kisses, boys, fifteen hundred Ex at thirty each and the delivery's here. Whatja think?

question: Of what?
answer: The face cream. Almond, marigold, chamomile, egg, aloe -- the "Almilk" formula. I remixed it.

question: Very nice.
answer: Reminds me, if you get downtown stop at Enhancements and pick up some almond oil -- not the California. What should we order?

question: Darling, it's Saturday.
answer: Thai. We haven't had Thai in a while.

question: Answer that. He'll call back every five minutes.
Well if you were the normal stupid fuck you should be so lucky to be and had one, you'd know it's supposed to rain --
Some farmer whacked his numerology on us.
Le Tour! -- finally. What took so long?
I need a quarter -- you got it?
answer: Robert said he sold you a quarter yesterday.

question: Some friends came over. How much is that? Fourteen-hundred?
answer: Eddie. Look at yourself. Sit down. I've known you, what, like eight years?

question: Yeah...
answer: Knew you from the other job, the one before the last one you fucked up. I knew your wife -- remember her? We used to sit and talk and talk --

question: You don't know what she was like --
answer: This is no good. I'll sell you a gram and some downs, but I ain't gonna put you in the emergency room. Cool it. Go to bed. Sleep it off.

question: You charge $200 for what goes for ninety on the street -- and you're not gonna sell?
I'll call Ann.
answer: Go ahead. You know what she'll say. Phone's over there.

question: I'll tell the fucking cops.
answer: Fuck you. That's it. You're out. Don't call again. Catch you next lifetime.

question: Please, Tour, I'm sorry. You're right. I didn't mean that. I'm quitting anyway. I'll take the gram. Sorry.
Two hundred?
answer: You got downs? One more thing. I gotta use the phone. I've got to go. Everybody wants to talk. It's like a compulsion. My philosophy is Me? I'm an old man. She'd break me like an old horse. Nah. Thanks anyway. I gotta go. Have fun. Carlos. Wait a second. Marianne! Marianne! Hop in! I'll give you a ride. John. John LeTour.

question: You got downs? One more thing. I gotta use the phone. I've got to go. Everybody wants to talk. It's like a compulsion. My philosophy is Me? I'm an old man. She'd break me like an old horse. Nah. Thanks anyway. I gotta go. Have fun. Carlos. Wait a second. Marianne! Marianne! Hop in! I'll give you a ride. John. John LeTour.
Where are you going? I didn't know you still lived here.
answer: Maybe this wasn't such a good idea. I should get out.

question: Don't be crazy. It's pouring.
answer: I'm not supposed to be around --

question: -- former drug associates.
answer: It's four years I'm clean. No alcohol, no cigarettes, no nothing.

question: I heard. I'm happy for you.
I know. Mar, you don't need to avoid me. I'm straight -- two years. It came that time. I tried to tell you. I wrote. I called.
Almond oil. You can check. Look. Shit.
answer: What's that for? In case someone needs almond oil in the middle of the night?

question: I still deal a little, but I'm straight -- that part's true. Believe me.
I won't say anything. I promise. I'll just sit here. I'll just give you a ride.
Where do you live? Mari... Eighty-third Street.
I'm not sure how this works.
answer: Have you ever been to a psychic before?

question: No, but I've, well, I've heard about it.
No... it's not that... I don't know -- I just decided to come. I thought...
answer: Be comfortable. How did you hear about me?

question: A recommendation. Somebody from work. Two hundred dollars, right?
I don't care.
answer: I look at you. I give you my impressions. I feel your "vibrations" -- I don't like that word, it sounds phony, but I can't think of anything better. You're anxious. More than usual. Your aura is very strong. I feel a very strong vibration from you. A change is coming. You're worried about money. You say you don't care about money but that's not true.

question: Yeah.
answer: Your livelihood is endangered. You're worried about the future. You don't have much money saved. What will you do?

question: I don't know.
answer: I see a woman who has betrayed you.

question: Not... I...
answer: Keep it in mind. I have a strong feeling about this woman, a woman close to you, she will betray you. You're in the entertainment business, aren't you?

question: Yes.
answer: But you're not happy. You want to do something else. Is it music?

question: Yes...
answer: You have a talent for music.

question: As a child.
answer: You still have it. It's strong. I see music in your future. A career opportunity will come in the music field. Take it. It won't seem promising. Take it anyway. You're full of stress. Are you exercising?

question: No. I --
answer: You should exercise more. You must let go of this stress. It's not good for your health. I'm not saying you're going over to the other side, but it's not good for you. You're still drinking, aren't you? You have a drinking problem? It's interfering with your health and your life too. You've had other problems. Drug addiction.

question: Yes.
answer: This was very important in your life.

question: Yes.
answer: You are in the balance. Everything you do -- positive or negative -- in this life is a drop that will carry over in the next. Every act, every decision matters.

question: I have trouble sleeping. Look. What do you see around me? Is there anything? Is it dark? Have I run out of luck? Is there luck?
answer: I see a glow. Everything you need is around you. The only danger is inside you.

question: Your pay's on the table.
answer: One hundred thirty-one, let's make it 130-$13,000, hundreds for small bills. One percent commission, $130 to you -- add tens or whatever if you want. Same time?

question: Two weeks -- don't run. Stay a while. We'll order kosher. We'll tell you dirty stories. We'll talk Zionism.
answer: I'm late already. I only come 'cause I like you. Sure you're not Jewish? I don't want to see you hurt. Find a man. You should do something else.

question: Invest in my cosmetics line.
answer: Don't mix business with friendship. Shalom.

question: Shalom. See you next week. Don't eat any hot dogs!
answer: Jealous said something about a yuppie murder in the Park. You know anything about it?

question: We're too small time. Besides, she wasn't one of ours -- not directly. Tis is at St. Luke's. He wants somebody over right away. Second floor waiting room.
answer: A hospital? What's he doing there?

question: He says he needs you to come to St. Luke's. I'd go but I got the other thing.
Mixed sushi. Oshitashi. What's going on?
What is it?
answer: You won't believe it. What a nightmare. I brought in this chick. She O.D.ed -- man, I didn't even know her. I didn't have to bring her in. The cops are coming back to talk to me. I'm hyper. I gotta come down.

question: The girl.
answer: Yeah, yeah. Met her last night. A walking vacuum cleaner. What a nightmare. Underage.

question: Randi?
answer: I can't believe it. Marianne's here too. She flew in. It's been so long. You look great.

question: You too. Randi, what's wrong? Why are you here?
answer: Mom. She's back in. Didn't Marianne tell you?

question: Can I see her?
answer: She's sleeping. She sleeps most of the time. She'd like it, though. She still talks about you.

question: I'm so sorry. She's a terrific woman. I was crazy about her. God.
Yes. Hi.
answer: Randi told me about your mom. I'm sorry.

question: This way. Kiss your mother for me. I like your mom.
answer: She liked you. You know this will happen someday, but when it does... Your mother -- that was a shock.

question: Your father?
answer: Not this time. His new wife -- he'll make it to the funeral.

question: What have you been doing? Where do you live?
answer: It's... I don't want you to know about my life.

question: Anything? You married? Have children? A dog? House plants?
The door to what? It's not like we're strangers. We were married.
There was a ceremony.
answer: He wasn't even a minister. He was an astrologer.

question: He was also a minister. "Universal Harmony."
In the eyes of Jeanne Dixon we're still --
We were happy.
answer: We were miserable. We were either scoring or coming down -- mostly coming down.

question: There were good times. Area, out on the street, laughing, dancing with friends -- we were magical.
answer: You took off for three months without telling me and called once. That's how magical we were. You were an encyclopedia of suicidal fantasies -- I heard them all. Nobody could clear a room like you, John. And the friends, you may have noticed, turned out to be mine, not yours. I envy you. A convenient memory is a gift from God.

question: You exaggerate.
answer: In rehab they call this "euphoric recall." You only remember the highs, never the lows.

question: You jumped --
answer: You did nothing -- "It wasn't your business, you weren't responsible" -- you still think like that. Actions have consequences; so do -- -- inactions.

question: We were happy? You bought it for me. It's inscribed inside. Ann's quitting. I've got to find something else to do.
answer: Ann? I'll believe it when I see it.

question: Yeah.
answer: Let me see your eyes. Eyes are deceiving. Congratulations.

question: If I could do that, I could do anything.
We could do anything. We could start over.
answer: What was that? I think I heard something.

question: I'll walk you. I can always find another way to make a living. I never planned this in the first place -- not like Ann. She came up to sell, have parties, make contacts. She was so glamorous. I just wanted to be around her. She'd sit up listening to coke stories. Now it's me and Robert. The whole crowd was the same age. Everybody's younger now. She made me.
There's some. Not much. A thousand or two. Maybe more -- I'm not sure.
answer: What do you do with your money?

question: I don't know. It's not that much in the first place -- as you know.
Rent, utilities, phone, tips, CDs -- what about your money?
answer: Kitty Ford once told me, "Ann, the only person I know that lives as well as you is my grandmother." All the money I've made, all the money I've spent -- it never adds up. This last two years cosmetics' been taking everything.

question: No, but I'm okay. What are the odds of meeting someone you haven't seen in years twice in two days?
answer: Ask Robert to make up a chart for you; the other person -- who is it?

question: Just a contact -- you don't know him.
We had this conversation two years ago. We'll have it two years from now.
I'm thinking of some music courses. Mixing, sound editing --
Why all this concern? Suddenly you care?
answer: I have feelings too -- you may have noticed. I guess I'm worried. I'm tough, you gotta to be tough, especially in this business, it's one thing to act tough -- I've seen Zipporah twice this week.

question: She helps you?
answer: -- harmonizes, she's encouraging me to get out of this into the cosmetics thing -- Nomination for Best Picture. I knew every girl he fucked -- how, why. I knew when he had trouble shitting. Like this. His wife says he gets straight or she cuts him off. Old money. I remember the last thing he said to me You'll still talk to me, won't you?

question: You --? Of course I will.
answer: It'll be strange without you around. I hadn't thought of it -- it hit me.

question: Ann, you want me, call, write a letter, tell a wino -- I'll be there. I'm sorry. I... I always thought my father would die first. He would die, then my mother and I would reconcile. Just her and me. I hated him for living.
answer: It's like a joke. It's not a real feeling. It's like a feeling of a feeling.

question: My old man bawling in the hospital, me popping in and out of the john getting loaded. I miss you.
answer: You tried to kill me. You took ten years of my life one way or another. I couldn't hate my mom -- I was too busy hating you.

question: I thought I was just killing myself. Selfish.
What?
answer: What it felt like. What this tasted like.

question: I see you and my heart starts thumping.
Have you ever had sex totally straight?
Never had anything like it stoned. Feel it.
Together. You need to go back?
answer: This is the end. It was wonderful. I'm glad it happened this way. It will never happen again. You will not see me, you will not call me again. I'm happy for you. I wish you the best. I'm leaving. I'm going back to the hospital. I shouldn't have left -- but I don't regret it. Please dress and leave as soon as possible. I have a key. Goodbye.

question: I love you.
answer: Johnny, what is this? Your beeper broke, gettin' some shiatsu? Two hours

question: There was a mix-up --
answer: How you gonna survive on your own? The U.N.'s got some conference in two days. The holiday's over -- ragheads everywhere trying to score. U.N. security at every hotel -- little creeps with lapel pins. Even I've been out. This is where our money is

question: Where's Robert?
answer: Busting his ass. He's out doing your job.

question: It was a confusion.
answer: Get confused on your day off.

question: When is that?
answer: Don't get wise. What do you want me to do? Suck your dick? -- okay. A raise? No way. Get out there. There's a list on the TV. I love you. Get your ass outta here before I kiss it.

question: I'm on my way. Love you. Forgive me.
answer: Tour, sit. Take a rest. LeTour, this is Gabri, Tasha -- you know Thomas. They're here for a show.

question: St. Luke's.
answer: No problem, but -- can you believe this? -- she's out of the hospital in one day, calls me up, wants to "get together." Some people are just born for losing. Want to go in back?

question: Look at the bar. Black-haired guy, late twenties, brown suit, drinking tonic? He's casing you. Not me, you. Undercover, whatever -- he's on you.
Leave a message. Robert or I will come by later.
answer: Forget it. It wasn't for me anyway. Who am I trying to impress? Make it tomorrow. A half -- no, three- quarters.

question: Nineteen is the top. I'll make two trips.

A domani. Take care, girls. I feel my life turning. All it needed was a direction. You drift from day to day, years go by. Suddenly there is a direction. What a strange thing to happen halfway through your life.
Marianne Jost.
answer: Just a moment. I'm sorry. Ms. Jost checked out this morning.

question: Did she leave a forwarding number?
Thank you. Mrs. Jost. JoAnn Jost. She's a patient. Skyline Floral. We're trying to confirm a delivery. Are the funeral arrangements local? Thank you. Can I help you, officer?
I hope I haven't made a mistake. You are a cop, aren't you?
What is it?
answer: You think you're invisible, don't you? You think we don't know you, LeTour -- that's the name you use, right?

question: My father's a partner in a powerful law firm. If you have anything in mind, do it by the book.
answer: You? Who the fuck cares about you? I could grind you right here! -- maybe I will! -- and nobody would give a fuck! You're not worth the paperwork. I look like Narcotics? I'm Homicide -- I'm investigating the Park murder.

question: I don't follow the news.
answer: Downtown's interested how a Barnard honors student with fancy parents got a quarter of uncut coke on her when she was murdered. I mean, we just don't see this girl cruising Alphabet City trying to score. Somebody sold her, somebody upscale and classy -- you're classy, I hear -- and that somebody knows something we need to know. Delivery boy!

question: I wish I could help. I don't even know who's president.
answer: Let me put it this way. Here's my card Ask around, take a week or so. Call me. Tell me something I don't know. Either that, leave town, or get your ass busted day in, day out.

question: Every time you come into my life something terrible happens. I thought I was rid of you. How'd you get here? I don't want you here! I don't want you around me, I don't want you around my mother! Damn you!
I didn't...
answer: I'm sorry. That's the way it is. You shouldn't have come. Marianne has been up all night, crying and crying. She wasn't there when Mother passed -- died -- she blames herself. It wouldn't have made any difference. She just slipped away. Marianne's -- I'm worried --

question: Yes, you. I can't think of anything, but if there was anything I could do...
answer: Thanks. I'm okay -- I guess. I mean, we've been expecting it. It'll hit me later.

question: Your mother. I came in the room. You were sleeping. I just watched.
answer: Oh. I'd better get back. Marianne's probably flipping out.

question: Sure, whatever. Surprise me.
answer: You gotta get permission? Check with Mama?

question: Yeah, the lawyer in Bronxville. I'm gonna ask him to come over. You've told me so much about him.
answer: No, don't. Please, I'll give you money, anything. He doesn't understand. Whose side are you on?

question: Is this Martin Jeer? Thank you.

I recommend Hazelden. It has the best all-around program. Martin Jeer? I'm here with your brother Ed. Yeah, in the city. I'm afraid there's a medical emergency. You're going to have to come. He'll be here.
answer: Tour, just in time. We were out. Nineteen, right?

question: Thirty-eight hundred -- got any hundreds?
answer: Some, not the whole thing. You got hundreds? I like that about Ann. Always takes the time to grind it. If you do it, do it right. Looks like you could use some help. Mari, this is Tour. You got any hundreds? Not the talkative type. Haven't seen her in years. You know her, don't you? Why they call me? What a nightmare. You want it or not?

question: What? Nowhere just now. Wait. Yes. Downtown.
John. John LeTour. Can I see you?
Open the door. You're awake anyway. Teresa. Read me. What do you see?
We had a session last week. What do you see?
Someone I knew died tonight.
answer: This was not an accident. This person was murdered.

question: Am I in danger?
answer: There is danger around you. It's very close. I'm sleepy.

question: Please. Am I lucky?
answer: Yes. Don't be afraid. Go home.

question: What do I owe you?
answer: Nothing. Forget it. Let me sleep.

question: This is John LeTour. Remember me?
You said I should ask around, tell you something you didn't know.
It ain't much, but it's something.
A girl died last night. Lexington Ave.
The news said she was alone in the apartment when she went out -- she wasn't. It's a cover-up. There was someone else.
That's all I know. You asked me to tell you something. I told you something.
Jack. Let me in.
answer: Where have you been? We were worried.

question: I need some sleep -- not much. I don't want to go home just yet. A little sleep first. Can I crash here? Nice place.
answer: It's hideous. I did it years ago. I've got to throw everything out. You haven't been here? Oh, Jack, this is Tony. I told you about him. You should talk. He's the lapidopterist -- gems. Same thing.

question: What do you know about Tis? What's his relationship to Ann?
answer: They go way back -- before me. Did you cross him?

question: No.
answer: Don't. He's Ann's Ecstasy connection. She needs that score. What happened?

question: Is he dangerous?
answer: Everybody's dangerous. We heard what you did to Eddie. Ann thought it was great. She was afraid that was why you didn't come back.

question: It was something else. Tell me if you hear anything.
Tis.
answer: Tis who? Ann says you want a chart done. What's wrong?

question: Yeah... You ever think about it?
That it'd be like this -- like, your life, you... that it would turn out this way? --
answer: Compared to what? My thinking this or that is going to make any difference? There's a plan unfolding. "Will my plane crash?" "Does life have meaning?" -- why ask me? Thinking's a fear of living, negative living; living's something else. You're afraid. Let the plan unfold. Stop. Stop, live one day -- one day --

question: Great.
answer: There's a plastic bottle of bath oil in the cabinet. Yellow. Use it -- tell me what you think. It's a new formula.

question: Burning Spear.
answer: How'd you get in? You buying?

question: I got a problem. I need a piece.
answer: Piece? Piece of what? Piece of candy?

question: Now. Anything. Am I speaking too fast?
The rate. What you got?
answer: He's got a 64 Smith-son. Detective Special. Nobody wants 'em. Fresh from a cop.

question: I don't have much use for a gun. Never used one like this.
What do you do?
answer: Simple. You put the bullets in -- you point it at the bad guys, pull the trigger and they fall down! Vaya con Dios.

question: -- Dios. Have you been to the police station?
answer: She was back on drugs. Really back. They're gonna bring her here too. My God. I thought she was playing for attention.

question: I didn't know.
answer: You're not to blame. Don't blame yourself. You weren't responsible. She was always -- she loved you.

question: She loved you. You were what she wanted to be.
You know him?
answer: His father's a lawyer. Did some tax things for Mom. He was at the hospital. What's that smell?

question: It's me. Cologne. I'm a sucker for that cheap airplane stuff. Did Marianne mention him yesterday?
answer: It was his apartment. What are you thinking?

question: I don't know.
answer: She jumped. You loved her, but she -- this sounds terrible but it's true -- she was... she ruined everything... bad luck.

question: Well, I got this thing to do. It's -- I don't know if I can get away.
Me?
answer: Yeah. Says you were supposed to show up again yesterday, but didn't.

question: A lie. I don't want to go. The suicide and all. Let's stay away.
answer: Can't. He's the Ecstasy connect. No way I can fuck this.

question: Since when?
answer: Just is -- so he's a bigot? What's new? So's everybody else.

question: It's going to be strange, not doing this. I mean I've had it, but sometimes...
answer: You're gonna do it, aren't you? You're gonna quit.

question: I think so. Seal this thing with Tis, turn it -- go with the cosmetics. You gotta take a chance in life. No risk, no gain. I've already got retail connections here, London. It was great at the beginning, though.
You know, when we first started out of the place on Greene Street. Before deliveries, when you were still using. It was open house every night but Sunday. We had everything

I should write a book someday. Did you know somebody wanted to do my story? Ghostwrite. It was impossible, of course -- my lawyer freaked I even had the meeting. People envy me. They think my life is so glamorous, but they don't know. I know. Glamorous. It was for a while. Then came crack and fucked everything.
answer: I gotta stop home a second.

question: Why? It's out of the way. They're expecting you.
answer: You know I got a bad vibe about Tis.

question: Chill. This is routine.
answer: I want to get my lucky jacket.

question: Oh. Okay. That took long enough. What did you do, douche while you were at it?
answer: Ann, you got some mouth on you.

question: You don't want to know where it's been. Cologne?
Phew. It smells like that stuff they give you on airplanes. It's no good for your skin. All chemicals. What's that?
What is it?
answer: If anything happens to me -- if I should like, you know, fucking die -- write and tell her. It's my sister. Her husband's in San Quentin. She worries, you know.

question: Okay.
answer: I thought we were going to Tis'?

question: We are. He's here. He can't very well work out of his apartment after what happened yesterday, can he? Mathis Bruge, please. Tis? Ann. I'm here with Tour. Okay.
Tour and I need to get our stories straight. Somebody's talking to the police. The guns were for emphasis, to make a point, dumb --
answer: We came together, we're leaving together. Johnny, come with me.

question: Thomas. Don't be stupid. Get out. Leave. I had nothing to do with Marianne -- she jumped
